name: Jackpot Canyon (Lake Mead NRA)
description:
Introduction

Also called Buzzard Canyon

Approach

The standard approach will be to park at the Weeping Springs trailhead. From here, hike up the 4x4 road until and follow the road until you get to a fork. There will be a fork in the road, go straight and continue down to the vista overlook where the road ends and where the descent begins.

Descent

From the top of the rim, pick a number of ways down into the obvious valley wash below and follow the wash into the drainage. Continue to follow the main drainage until the canyon starts to narrow. Enjoy the hike through some scenic narrow corridors that meander down into a few downclimbs. The canyon walls start to rise and not to long after, the canyon opens up to a two-stage rap sequence.

R1: The anchorage is webbing choaked from a small tree. The rap goes down 30 ft. to a platform that can fit 4 maybe 5 people at the most. R2: has master point anchorage, canyon right and goes down 200 ft. This rap has some loose rock on the wall.

(APRIL 2023 UPDATE)

R1: Because the bolts were removed, the first two rappels are combined into one multistage rappel. The anchor is currently built around a chockstone in the ground, center canyon. Make sure to add a 10' extension to get it over the lip for a clean pull when you finish Stage 2. A 70m rope and toggle were perfect!

Stage 1 (~30'): Rappel canyon left to a platform that can fit 5 people.

Unlike the previous beta, there are no more bolts and almost no option to build a natural anchor at the platform. If you pull the rope pre-emptively, climbing back up is very risky and difficult.

Stage 2 (~180'): Because of the new angle from the adjusted anchor, the rope rubs over some pretty sharp rock, canyon left. Edge protection is suggested!

There is a "cave" at the base of the rap. If you choose to enter, bring a light to see the coloring on the walls. Ensure that nobody is above you is kicking rocks down as you approach or exit the cave. Rap 2 is a dense gravity zone and rocks were coming down. The cave qualifies per the Nevada standard, but it only has 50-60 ft of passage.

Afterwards, there is a series of boulder downclimbs to the second section of narrows. The walls get high, and the canyon continues to a downclimb. Continuing down, you will come up to a 30 ft rap that is choaked by webbing from a small tree. Immediately afterwards you will encounter another 70 ft rap with an anchorage, canyon right. Once down, continue to another 20 ft rap from an anchorage, canyon left. After this rap you will come up to the final rap sequence.

You will see the river from this point and the last three raps are through some scenic narrow meandering canyon. This is my favorite section of the canyon. The first rap is 40ft. from an anchorage, canyon right. The second is a 30 ft rap from an anchorage, canyon left. Here you will have a series of platforms where up to 5 people can fit. Inflate your rafts here. The last rap is 30 ft using an anchorage, canyon left. This rap will take you right into the water so you must be prepared to deploy your already inflated raft into the water and rappel into your packraft. You are now in the colorado river.

Bring webbing and rapides to replace any required anchorage.

Link to download KML: http://ropewiki.com/File:Jackpot_Canyon_.kml

Exit

Paddle up stream to big horn canyon and use the beta for the bighorn canyon exit to hike back to your car at the top of the rim.

As of Fall 2023, Bighorn Canyon is incredibly, perhaps dangerously overgrown in the stretch between the beach and the narrows. We also encountered a large rattlesnake (speckled or arizona diamondback) in the bushwhacking, but the concern is that it is so thick you could easily step on a rattlesnake and not know it until you're bit. Better alternative would be to packraft down to cranes nest to an exit vehicle.

Red tape

There is no red tape as far as I am aware of but there are a few things to keep in mind. When we showed up to this canyon, we were prepared to "groom the gardens" as a first descent with natural anchorage systems, webbing, rock, knot choaks, Deadman anchorages systems, fiddlesticks, CEM, etc....but we found that the canyon was already explored. We found most of the raps were bolted with hangers that have been painted natural colors. You must have a USCG approved PFD and packraft to float on the colorado river. Parking at the weeping springs trailhead will be good for high clearance. If you have a 4x4 high clearance with good tires, you can continue to drive to the final rim where you descend down. That final section of road get a bit more face value.

Please remember that installation of permanent fixed hardware is strictly prohibited in Black Canyon Wilderness area, and the entirety of LMNRA. No bolts.

Beta sites

Background

Rick Ianniello recorded the first known descent in his guide book,Las Vegas Slots. It is known as "Buzzard canyon".

Background

We showed up to this canyon ready to " groom the gardens " as a first descent but found out that this canyon has already been visited.
